awd_titl_txt: Understanding Reaction Mechanisms for the Design of RF Driven Catalytic Modular Reactors
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed project will investigate the concept of driving catalytic reactions on the surface of iron oxide nanoparticles that are locally heated by exposure to radio frequency (RF) radiation. The main objective is to develop a new process that is more energy efficient than thermally-driven ones and to design a modular reactor system for RF-driven catalytic reactions at low temperatures.  Low reaction temperatures are expected to prevent catalyst degradation by reducing coke formation and particle sintering, while reducing the energy consumption in chemical manufacturing processes. 

The fundamental principles behind the RF-driven oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes on Fe3O4 nanoparticles will be studied, including the effects of the energy conversion/transfer on reaction mechanisms. The size and structure of the nanoparticles will be optimized to maximize energy conversion. Chemical reactions will be investigated using standard methods and neutron/synchrotron characterization techniques. Interactions with magnetic fields will be modeled using open-source software to elucidate the interaction between catalytically active Fe surface sites, orientation within magnetic fields, and generated energy. The fundamental knowledge on RF-driven catalytic reactions will be used to design a modular reactor that can be scaled-up to industrial level. In addition to training graduate students in an interdisciplinary research field, the PIs plan to use magnetic nanoparticles to develop material for educational and outreach activities to K-12 students from the Baton Rouge, LA, area and undergraduate students from local HBCUs, with special emphasis on encouraging students from underrepresented minority groups to pursue careers in science and engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Louisiana State University and A&M College

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Overview:  In this project we examined radiofrequency-induction heating (RF-IH) as a method to indirectly heat reactors for three different chemical processes that involve catalytic reactions important to chemicals production - one important to biomass upgrading, another to shale gas usage and the production of a wide variety of chemical intermediates, and the third important to the recycling of waste polymers.

Intellectual Merit:  For each process, we made catalysts that were not only effective for the targeted reactions, but also satisfied the requirements of the RF-IH indirect heating.  We tested these catalysts in laboratory scale reactor systems with heat generated in the reactors by RF-IH.  In all three cases we showed that we could improve the selectivities to certain desired products of these reactions. In many cases, we showed that we could improve the catalyst activities and lifetimes as well.  We were able to attain the required process temperatures easily with the combination of specially engineered catalyst structures and indirect RF-IH heating.  We also correlated the heat generation and energy transfer mechanisms with the catalyst compositions and structures, in particular their surface structures.

Broader Impact:

The results of this research will assist the chemical industry in its current decarbonization efforts, by substituting RF-IH (where the electricity could be generated from non-fossil fuel sources) for conventional process heating, where most of the energy supplied is generated by burning fossil fuels. The chemical industry greatly desires this goal, as evidenced by their enthusiastic backing of the LSU NSF Engines Proposal (currently under consideration) on energy transition for the state of Louisiana, one of the largest per capita energy use states in the US. 

Three Ph.D., one M.S. and six undergraduate student workers were trained in whole or in part on this project.  All of them still are in STEM-related occupations, either engaged in advanced study, working in industry, or still at the B.S.-level.  The results of the project have been publicly disseminated (so far, more to come) in five refereed publications, 12 conference presentations, one patent application, and two Ph.D. theses.

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2023
Modified by: Kerry M Dooley
